prior_works.title: Gaussian Processes for Machine Learning
prior_works.authors: Carl E. Rasmussen, Christopher K. I. Williams
prior_works.role: Foundational theory for Gaussian process regression and kernel design
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Kermut’s supervised predictor and calibrated uncertainty stem directly from GP posterior inference and kernel-centric modeling principles formalized in this book.

prior_works.title: Convolution Kernels on Discrete Structures
prior_works.role: Foundational framework for composing kernels over structured objects
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Kermut’s composite kernel over sets of mutations follows the convolution-kernel idea of building valid kernels by combining parts, enabling similarity to be defined over mutation sets rather than raw sequences.

prior_works.title: Additive Gaussian Processes
prior_works.authors: David Duvenaud, Hannes Nickisch, Carl E. Rasmussen
prior_works.role: Kernel constructions that decompose functions into main effects and interactions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Kermut’s kernel explicitly aggregates contributions from single mutations and their interactions (epistasis), aligning with additive/interaction GP kernels that capture low-order structure in high-dimensional spaces.

prior_works.title: The Spectrum Kernel: A String Kernel for SVM Protein Classification
prior_works.authors: Christina Leslie, Eleazar Eskin, William Stafford Noble
prior_works.role: Sequence-kernel paradigm linking biological sequence similarity to predictive performance
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By demonstrating how sequence similarity can be encoded into a kernel, this work motivates Kermut’s mutation-similarity kernelization as a biologically informed alternative to naive Hamming distances.

prior_works.title: Amino Acid Substitution Matrices from Protein Blocks (BLOSUM)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Kermut’s mutation-similarity component leverages the notion that substitutions are unequal; BLOSUM-style priors provide the canonical blueprint for weighting amino-acid changes in a kernel.

prior_works.title: Navigating the protein fitness landscape with Gaussian processes
prior_works.authors: Peter A. Romero, Andreas Krause, Frances H. Arnold
prior_works.role: Early demonstration of GP models and uncertainty for protein sequence–function landscapes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This study established GPs as effective supervised models for protein variant effects with meaningful uncertainty, a direct precursor to Kermut’s GP framework tailored with a biologically grounded composite kernel.

prior_works.title: Disease variant prediction with deep generative models of evolutionary data (EVE)
prior_works.authors: Jonathan Frazer, Pascal Notin, Mafalda Dias, Aidan Brock, Yarin Gal, Debora Marks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EVE popularized reporting and leveraging uncertainty in variant-effect predictions; Kermut advances this by providing GP-based posterior uncertainty with supervised, state-of-the-art accuracy.

synthesis_narrative:
Kermut’s core contribution—a supervised Gaussian process model with a composite kernel that encodes mutation similarity and epistasis while yielding calibrated posterior uncertainty—builds on a confluence of ideas from kernel methods, GP modeling, and protein variant prediction. The GP framework of Rasmussen and Williams provides the mathematical backbone for nonparametric regression and principled uncertainty quantification. Haussler’s convolution kernels motivate constructing valid kernels over structured objects, enabling Kermut to define similarity directly over sets of mutations rather than entire sequences. To capture the structure of genotype–phenotype maps, Kermut adopts an additive/interactions perspective akin to Additive Gaussian Processes, allowing main effects of single substitutions and low-order epistatic interactions to be composed cleanly within the kernel.
In encoding biologically meaningful similarity, the spectrum/string-kernel tradition (Leslie et al.) demonstrates how sequence-derived similarity boosts predictive performance, while BLOSUM substitution matrices supply a long-standing prior that not all amino-acid changes are equal—guiding Kermut’s mutation-similarity term. Empirically, earlier applications of GPs to protein fitness landscapes (Romero, Krause, Arnold) validated GPs’ suitability for supervised sequence–function learning and highlighted the utility of predictive uncertainty for design and exploration. Finally, the EVE framework crystallized the community’s emphasis on uncertainty in variant-effect prediction; Kermut advances this agenda by delivering supervised state-of-the-art accuracy together with GP posterior uncertainties and an analysis of calibration, enabled by its biologically grounded composite kernel.
